titlestmt.titleproper: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests, Series E
A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests, Series E FA314

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests, Series E

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records are arranged by subject matter in 27 series. Most of these series are wholly or partially open for research. The series are:

A John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; C Business Interests; D Civic Interests; E Cultural Interests; F Economic Reform Interests; G Educational Interests; H Friends and Services; I Homes; J Housing Interests; K Medical Interests; L Real Estate; M Maps and Memorabilia; N Religious Interests; O Rockefeller Boards; P Welfare - General Files; Q World Affairs; R Welfare - Youth Files; S Documents; T Public Relations; U Public Land Law Review Commission; V Greenrock; W Properties; X Costume Collection; Y Media; Z John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Personal; AA Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; AC Abby Rockefeller Mauz√©

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The central figure in the creation and operation of the Standard Oil Company during its rise to the top of the petroleum industry, John D. Rockefeller (JDR) established for the family a leading role in business and philanthropy. From the days of his earliest employment, Rockefeller, a devout Baptist, was generous in his giving to worthy causes, especially those of a religious nature. During the 1890s he developed an orderly system of philanthropic giving through an office staff that included his close advisor, Frederick T. Gates (1853-1929) and his son, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960). With the advise of these and other associates, Rockefeller established the University of Chicago, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now The Rockefeller University), the Rockefeller Foundation, and other philanthropic organizations working nationally and internationally in the fields of education, religion, and health. Rockefeller's total donations to philanthropic endeavors are estimated to have been $540 million.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (JDR Jr.) joined his father's office on October 1, 1897. He oversaw the expansion and diversification of the philanthropic work begun by his father. During his lifetime, the younger Rockefeller gave more than $537 million to educational, religious, cultural, medical, and other charitable projects.

John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller (1874-1948), passed the Rockefeller philanthropic impulse on to their children. John D. 3rd (1906-1978), Nelson A. (1908-1979), Laurance S. (1910-2004), Winthrop (1912-1973), and David (1915-) further expanded and diversified Rockefeller influence and interests, establishing their own philanthropic organizations, most notably the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (1940), and becoming more active politically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller (OMR) materials document the increasing role assumed by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in the management of Rockefeller affairs and amply document his business and philanthropic affairs. They also chronicle the entrance of JDR Jr.'s sons, John D. 3rd, Nelson A., Laurance S., Winthrop, and David, into the world of business, philanthropy, civic leadership, and politics as they joined the office.

This material contains correspondence, reports, pamphlets, memoranda, deeds, maps, contracts, reports, minutes, charters, certificates of incorporation, clippings, diaries, notebooks, calendars, and memorabilia.
There is a microfilm card index of personal and institutional names.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in nineteen sections:

Chautauqua Institute; Historical Monuments; Libraries; Memorials; Milbank Memorial Fund; Motion Pictures; Museums; Music; Organizations and Parks; Palisades Interstate Park; Plant, Flower, and Fruit Guild; Radio and Television; Restorations; Chinese Restorations; French Restorations; Old Ironsides; Colonial Williamsburg; Theatre; Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cultural Interests series reflects the Rockefeller family's involvement and contributions in the areas of the arts, museums, parks, and historic restorations. The series contains correspondence between members of the Rockefeller family and the Family Office Staff on the one hand, and officials and members of the various institutions and organizations on the other. Most of the material concerns unsolicited appeals for donations. Some members of the family were also members of or were active in several of the organizations, and some of the correspondence reflects this activity.

The family members who figure most prominently in this series are John D. Rockefeller Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and David Rockefeller. John D. Rockefeller Sr., Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, Abby Rockefeller Mauz√©, Blanchette Hooker Rockefeller, Mary French Rockefeller, Margaret (Peggy) McGrath Rockefeller, and Martha Baird Rockefeller also appear.

The Colonial Williamsburg section of the Cultural Interests series comprises 29 manuscript boxes of material covering the years 1926-1961. While this section does not cover all aspects of the restoration from the initiation of the idea in 1926 through John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s death in 1960, most major facets of this massive project are included. The main focus of this material is on John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s participation in the origin and development of the idea of restoring the Tidewater city to its authentic mid-eighteenth-century condition. There are folders for each of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s gifts, which totaled over $450 million by 1960. The financial history of the restoration can be traced through a series of Treasurer's reports, operating budgets, and annual reports, as well as memoranda between John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Kenneth Chorley, Carlisle Humelsine, Vernon Geddy, and John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

The quality and inclusiveness of the documentary material drops sharply after 1954, as a consequence of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s increasing age, the retirement of Kenneth Chorley, the modest financial success of the restoration, and the resignation of John D. Rockefeller 3rd from the Chairmanship. This last event provides an interesting counterpoint to the main theme of the Colonial Williamsburg files and one fully covered by the documents included here. John D. Rockefeller 3rd supported his father's efforts to complete the historical restoration, but he also hoped to use Williamsburg for broader educational and less antiquarian purposes. During the entire period of his tenure as Chairman (1939-1953), but especially during the years 1948-1952, he sought to convince his father and fellow trustees that Williamsburg could play a central role in the effort to revitalize American democracy and to remind the country of its political and economic heritage. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's resignation stemmed from John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s growing reluctance to see any resources diverted from the central objective of restoring Williamsburg.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For additional information about Palisades Interstate Park, see also the Mark M. Jones Papers at the Rockefeller Archive Center.

Chautauqua Institution

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitations to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to speak at Chautauqua declined; appeals for aid declined. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Arthur E. Bestar, Arthur W. Packard.

scopecontent.p: Contributions by John D. Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. $15,000 gift to reduce indebtedness.

did.unittitle: Historical Monuments, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A proposed non-profit corporation to undertake the restoration and preservation of historic buildings in New York state. Corporation not formed, but a bill passed in New York legislature permitting historical societies to charge admission. This was done for the Philipse Manor House while it was run by the Tarrytown Historical Society. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Hugh Grant Rowell, Thomas Dewey.

did.unittitle: Libraries
Libraries - New York Public Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contributions toward operating deficits, endowment, Donnell Branch on West 53rd Street, and general purposes. Contributions by Mary French Rockefeller; various members of family send books to library as gifts. Studies of library operation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Beardsley Ruml, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Mary French Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Libraries - New York Public Library - Music Museum and Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appeals for contributions to music department of library; plans for a music library museum. Nelson A. Rockefeller gave $10,000 toward promotion of idea, but it never became a reality. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, C. S. Smith.

did.unittitle: Libraries - New York Public Library - Beardsley Ruml Report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial and management study of library operations; led to John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s 1922-23 pledge. Report in file is not the final copy. Correspondents include Beardsley Ruml.

Rockefeller contribution, 1946. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur Woods, Kenneth Chorley, Arthur W. Packard, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur Woods, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, Luther Evans, Herbert Putnam.

did.unittitle: Memorials - Pacific War Memorial

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to establish scientific research foundation in Pacific area as memorial. Laurance S. Rockefeller deeply involved in initial planning, but he withdrew as director in 1948. Packard, Winthrop Rockefeller, Archibald Roosevelt.

did.unittitle: Memorials - Nature Centers for Young America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly called William T. Hornaday Memorial Foundation and National Foundation for Junior Museums. (Hornaday founded the Bronx Zoo.) Memorial planned to develop children's interest in natural history; J. R. Forbes the driving force in opening children's museums all over country. In 1961, merged with National Audubon Society. Laurance S. Rockefeller and Rockefeller Brothers Fund contributions. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Carl O. Gustafson, J. R. Forbes.

did.unittitle: Memorials - Booker T. Washington Memorial Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seek to establish a Booker T. Washington School of Industrial Training at Washingtons birthplace. General Education Board (GEB), Rockefeller brothers, and Rockefeller Foundation suspected commercialism of venture, doubted merit of goal; refused to contribute. Memorial went bankrupt, due to lack of Negro support, according to S. Phillips, its head and apparently a defender of segregation. Correspondents include V. M. Geddy, S. J. Phillips, Jackson Davis, Dana S. Creel, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Memorials - Booker T. Washington Memorial Association
Memorials - Booker T. Washington Memorial Association - Booker T. Washington Monument Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bankrupt Association under a new name, and with a new project. Ask Rockefeller Brothers Fund to buy birthsite property and donate it to government as a national monument; brothers declined.

did.unittitle: Milbank Memorial Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of Milbank's paper on the Fall of the Banker from Grace; Milbank advocated strengthening of "social viewpoint" to modify excessively individualistic capitalist system, prevent future depressions. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interest in Fund's health work in China; correspondence about Kingsbury's booklet, "Red Medicine" and Soviet challenge to western social conscience. John D. Rockefeller 3rd interest in Fund's research on population problems in Asia. Correspondents include Albert Milbank, Dr. William Welch, John Kingsbury, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Motion Pictures - Vitarama Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller invested in corporation; Navy interest in projector system for gunnery training, production for Navy. Shift to peace-time work. Licensing of Cinerama to use processes. Laurance S. Rockefeller and Fred Waller held majority of stock; in 1950, Laurance S. Rockefeller resigned as director. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Ralph Walker, Fred Waller, R. B. Marston.

did.unittitle: Motion Pictures - Cinerama Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organization of corporation; Laurance S. Rockefeller investment; development of Waller's inventions used by Vitarama, in making military training films. Production problems, securing additional financing, search for a market. Laurance S. Rockefeller sold his interests in 1950. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Lowell Thomas, R. B. Marston, Fred Waller.

did.unittitle: Museums
Museums - American Museum of Natural History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1902, William Rockefeller was a trustee. Early gifts. Starr J. Murphy-Frederick T. Gates disagreement about contributions to endowment fund. Special contributions to various projects and expeditions. Large John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gift to endowment, 1922. Advisers' doubts about Museum administration; President Osborn's retirement. Printed material; declinations of various appeals and invitations. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, Willard S. Richardson, Starr J. Murphy, Thomas B. Appleget, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Roy Chapman Andrews, Henry Osborn, Morris Jesup, Nicholas Murray Butler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include David Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Third Asiatic Expedition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Led by Roy Chapman Andrews; seeking origin of primitive man. Chapman letters to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. describing expedition and its troubles in Chinese Civil War. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $37,500 to help finance expedition.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Crew of the Half Moon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Group of important professional men who go on dinner-table "voyages" with explorer guest speakers. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. attended but didn't join.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Planetarium

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material on invention of apparatus and the first U.S. planetariums. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined to help Museum buy one; eventually Charles Hayden gift made purchase possible. John D. Rockefeller 3rd was a member of Museum's Planetarium Authority. Tentative plans for putting planetarium in Rockefeller Center. Norman Bel Geddes' report on Planetarium. Correspondents include F. Fieseler, F. T. Davison, Henry Osborne, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Planetarium

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material on invention of apparatus and the first U.S. planetariums. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined to help Museum buy one; eventually Charles Hayden gift made purchase possible. John D. Rockefeller 3rd was a member of Museum's Planetarium Authority. Tentative plans for putting planetarium in Rockefeller Center. Norman Bel Geddes' report on Planetarium. Correspondents include F. Fieseler, F. T. Davison, Henry Osborne, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - David Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: David Rockefeller contributions for purchase of beetle collections and to pay salary of beetle specialist. Sets up Rockefeller Coleoptera Fund and David Rockefeller Fund. Requests for non-entomological gifts declined; declined to become Trustee. Much discussion of bugs. Correspondents include Mont Cazier, Jerome Rozen, Jr., David Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - David Rockefeller - Southwest Research Station

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: David Rockefeller helps establish and maintain biological laboratory in Arizona. David Rockefeller-Mont Cazier correspondence about Station's progress and their mutual beetle collections. David Rockefeller designated Benefactor of Museum. Printed material and photos. Correspondents include David Rockefeller, Mont Cazier, Detlev Bronk, Willis Gertsch.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - David Rockefeller - Southwest Research Station

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: David Rockefeller helps establish and maintain biological laboratory in Arizona. did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Laurance S. Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller a Life Member and Associate Benefactor. Laurance S. Rockefeller and Mary French Rockefeller annual contributors. Consideration of Leonard Outhwaite for Museum post. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Leonard Outhwaite.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - Nelson A. Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller an Associate Member; loans of Peruvian textiles; gifts of Peruvian mummy bundles and primitive art. In 1952, $1,000 nonrecurring contribution. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, F. T. Davison.

did.unittitle: Museums - American Museum of Natural History - John D. Rockefeller 3rd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1933, John D. Rockefeller 3rd joined Board of Trustees and various committees. Correspondence about museum finances, charter revisions, museum work in prisons and schools, personnel changes, the Ten-Year Program, war and post-war problems, various Museum projects and expeditions. 1944 Director's Report; 1947 plans for reducing Museum budget and for modernization. President Parr's addresses on the purpose of a museum; plans for new auditorium; retirement policies. In 1953, John D. Rockefeller 3rd was elected Benefactor; in 1955, he resigned from the Board. Correspondents include F. T. Davison, A. S. Parr, Charles Russell, Burton Turnbull, Robert Moses, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Museums - Jerusalem Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller. Jr.'s offer of gift for museum; conditions; letters of appreciation. Construction, opening of museum, 1935; internationalization of Board of trustees, 1948, when British mandate ended. Discovery of Dead Sea Scrolls. Relations between Jerusalem Museum and Oriental Institute. Political changes in Near East threatening Museum's work. Additional John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gifts for special work; discussion of Jordanian nationalization of Museum. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, Raymond B. Fosdick, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Montgomery S. Bradley, James Breasted, Lord Plumer, Carl Kraeling.

did.unittitle: Museums - Jerusalem Museum - Dead Sea Scrolls

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Carl Kraeling reports on scrolls; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. pledges up to $30,000 to the Oriental Institute to prepare the scrolls at the Museum. In 1957, Jordan's government nationalizes scrolls; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. continues payments on pledge, but pays Jordanian government instead of Oriental Institute directly. Clippings. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dana S. Creel, Dr. Carl Kraeling.

scopecontent.p: Gift of Billings property to Museum for Cloisters; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest in planning and construction; Nelson A. Rockefeller on planning committee. Purchase of special items. Opening of Cloisters; management and operation; changes in exhibits. J. J. Rorimer's war-time experiences; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s continuing interest in the Cloisters. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, Robert deForest., J. J. Rorimer, N. D. Taylor.

did.unittitle: Museums - Metropolitan Museum of Art - Cloisters - Offer of Tapestries and Furniture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gift in 1935 reserved life interest to him; objects turned over to Museum in 1937. Search for additional pieces of furniture.

did.unittitle: Museums - Metropolitan Museum of Art - Cloisters - Purchase of Brummer Collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Negotiations between John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Rorimer, and Brummer; purchase included tapestries.

did.unittitle: Museums - Metropolitan Museum of Art - Cloisters - Offer to Museum and Acceptance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Details of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s offer to finance construction of Cloisters and to provide the land; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. authorizations for architects and construction.

did.unittitle: Museums - Metropolitan Museum of Art - Cloisters - Hanging Gothic Tapestries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s ideas on proper display of tapestries; gift to cover expenses of rearrangement.

did.unittitle: Museums - Metropolitan Museum of Art - Cloisters - Pledge for Spanish Frescoes

scopecontent.p: Special contribution to purchase 12th century frescoes.

scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. purchased Spanish tomb for $82,000 for Cloisters.

Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, W. E. Winlock, H. Kent.

did.unittitle: Museums - George Gray Barnard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Barnard's idea for Gothic Museum on his land; urged John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to purchase French collection. Bosworth investigated idea for John D. Rockefeller, Jr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. bought land on Hudson, and Gothic Collection; disagreement with Barnard over display policies. Museum idea tabled. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. stored Gothic pieces at Pocantico. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gives Billings estate to city for Gothic Museum. Barnard's contributions to idea of Cloisters; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.s relations with Barnard. Barnard's Monastery"; his death; plans for memorials. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George Gray Barnard, W. W. Bosworth, Charles O. Heydt, Raymond B. Fosdick.

did.unittitle: Music - Associated Glee Clubs of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attempt to encourage male glee clubs in industry and among youth; use of competitive singing to raise standards. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $500 in 1925; $750 in 1926, $750 in 1928. Declined request for contribution toward endowment, 1928. No contributions after 1928. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Music - American Lyric Theatre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A theater to present in English modern and classical works of lyric drama, lasted until 1942. Nelson A. Rockefeller gave it strong support, $15,000. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Music - Columbia Summer Concerts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. made annual contributions to Edwin Frank Goldman band for summer concerts, 1919-1922, given on Columbia University campus. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $2,500 annually, stopped when concerts moved to Central Park. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Willard S. Richardson.

Music - Institute of Musical Art, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Damrosch plan for school of music in New York with million dollar endowment. Endowment plan did not materialize. John D. Rockefeller made some contributions in 1906-1907. He pledged $10,000 toward new building in 1909, but terms of building pledge were not matched and money wasn't given. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Starr J. Murphy, Frank Damrosch, Alta Rockefeller Prentice.

scopecontent.p: Little Theater Opera Company changed its name to New York Opera Comique in 1931. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $10,000 to aid company, declined later requests. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: League program to arouse interest in music among New York City children; Sunday Schools participated in mass singing. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $250 in 1922; contributed $2500 to enlarged year-round program. Later appeals declined. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Arthur W. Packard.

scopecontent.p: Gathering of information on need for such a center; selection of consultants. John D. Rockefeller 3rd a member of exploratory committee. Preliminary planning; negotiations with Juilliard School of Music. Development of a philosophy; comments and criticisms of plans; organization of corporation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young, Wallace K. Harrison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discussion of size and shape of proposed concert hall. Problems of acoustics and comfort; decision on Philharmonic Hall and smaller concert halls. Criticisms of decisions. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for dance center; ideas for dance companies. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Employees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organizational staff plans; selection of Maxwell Taylor, and later William Schuman, as presidents of Center. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Employees - Executive Director

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Employment of consultant to aid in search. Qualifications of applicants; selection of Reginald Allen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applicants for positions with Center, many with strong recommendations. Referred to Lincoln Center staff for disposition.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Development of philosophy for education in Center; selection of Juilliard as major vehicle. Suggestions for educational facilities. Emphasis on advanced training in music, opera, ballet and drama. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young, William Schuman, Aaron Copeland.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Juilliard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Selection of Juilliard; program of participation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Museum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for Museum in Center. Selection of New York Public Library to control museum on music and the dance. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Tenant Relocation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appeals for assistance from tenants moved; reports on progress of work; final report on relocation. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edgar B. Young.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Opera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for opera house. Welles Bosworth's objections to preliminary designs; John D. Rockefeller 3rd's response to his objections. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Welles Bosworth.

did.unittitle: Music - Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts - Repertory Drama

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for drama; potential audience for repertory drama. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Music - Stadium Concerts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. helped underwrite concerts; he gave $500 annually, and the amount increased regularly to $2500 in 1934. Contributions by other members of family and through Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Martha Baird Rockefeller contributions. Correspondents include Minnie Guggenheimer, Adolph Lewisohn, Willard S. Richardson, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Martha Baird Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Music - Schubert Memorial

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller each subscribe $1,000 to program to assist young artists in initial recitals. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel.

did.unittitle: Music - Westchester Choral Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. sent $25 in 1929 as contributing member; he sent $100 from 1930-1934; he sent $40 in 1936. Did not attend concerts or show any special interest. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Arthur W. Packard.

scopecontent.p: Contribution toward summer festival.

did.unittitle: Music - Westchester Friends of Music, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Music - Metropolitan Opera Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s reluctance to support opera; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller annual membership until 1938; no further interest until Laurance S. Rockefeller gift of $500 in 1949. Metropolitan's search for a new home; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contribution to cost of study of possible new site for Opera House. John D. Rockefeller 3rd's work with Metropolitan in connection with Lincoln Center. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Anthony Bliss, Rudolf Bing.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - American Historical Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A. Beveridge and G. Ford ask John D. Rockefeller, Jr. to contribute, 1925; declined. In 1927, $10,000 given for study of national and linguistic origins in America of 1790. No later requests or contributions. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., A. Beveridge, Thomas B. Appleget.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - American Association for Medical Progress

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Society of laymen endorsing medical research, primarily vivisection. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined to join, but gave $7,800, 1925-1928. Correspondents include Raymond B. Fosdick, Thomas B. Appleget.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Arbitration Society of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: To foster and organize tribunal to handle controversies which are questions of fact rather than matters of law, to ease court congestions. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $2,500. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Raymond B. Fosdick.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - American Arbitration Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consolidation of several arbitration organizations. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest stemmed from activities in Chamber of Commerce; he made regular small contributions until 1942. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur W. Packard, Arthur Woods, Dana S. Creel.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - American Arbitration Association - Inter-American Commercial Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commercial arbitration, principally between the nationals of various American states. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $42,000. Relation to Chamber of Commerce. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - American Planning and Civic Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to cultivate high ideals of civic life and beauty in America, and improve landscape. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave to budget. Cooperation with National Park Service. Abby Aldrich Rockefeller 1935 gift to improve highway landscapes; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interest in work of Association. Correspondents include Arthur W. Packard, Arthur Woods, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Horace Albright.

Organizations and Parks - China Institute in America, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Institute acted as collective guardian of Chinese students sent to America by Box Indemnity money; emphasis on education and culture. Postwar planning of activities before Red Revolution. Emergency relief for Chinese students stranded by Civil War. Invitations declined; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined appeals for contributions. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur W. Packard, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Stephen Duggan.

No contributions between 1952 and 1958. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Arthur W. Packard, Charles P. Noyes.

Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - New York City Anti-Crime Committee, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Waged campaign against racketeering on the New York waterfront. 1953 evaluation of committee's work; split in committee over actions of chief investigator in wire tapping scandal. Collapse of committee, 1956. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, Dana S. Creel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $50,000 toward monument to be built at Verdun; chapels and repository for bones. Letter of acknowledgement from Marshall Petain. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Thomas B. Appleget, Marshall Petain.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - First Avenue Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Office membership, 1928-1932; John D. Rockefeller 3rd not a member, but made several small contributions. Name changed to East Side Association in 1960. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Charles O. Heydt.

scopecontent.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller a member of board of New York office located in Radio City. No contributions. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Rene Chambrun.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General conservation organization with special interest in soil conservation. Unsuccessful attempt to interest Laurance S. Rockefeller. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Freedoms Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to honor those advancing American way of life, tended to be politically rightist. No interest by Rockefellers. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

Organizations and Parks - Far East-America Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to develop sound two-way trade between U.S. and Far East. John D. Rockefeller 3rd interest expressed through attendance at dinners. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organized to stimulate American interest in Asia. John D. Rockefeller 3rd made a nonrecurring gift through Fund for National Sports Clubs of India. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Donald McLean.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Hall of Our History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Uncompleted plans for large stone carvings of scenes from American history; appeals for contributions declined. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Holland House Corporation - Netherland-America Foundation

scopecontent.p: Foundation rented space in Rockefeller Center Holland House; Nelson A. Rockefeller spoke informally at several meetings. Attempts to interest family in organization failed. Correspondents include Dana S. Creel, Arthur W. Packard, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Hudson River Conservation Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to preserve scenery along Hudson; successful in halting quarrying on Palisades; made survey of river front; gained state ownership of small pieces of scenic property. Interested in east bank properties; negotiations for Mount Taurus; oil pollution in river. Laurance S. Rockefeller became vice-president; his diminishing interest in Society. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard.

Organizations and Parks - Van Cortlandt Manor House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest in Manor House aroused through Hudson River Conservation Society; Hugh Grant Rowell's advice; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s visit to House. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest maintained until 1953, when he purchased it; decision to restore it. House turned over to Sleepy Hollow Restorations when restorations completed. Negotiations with local governments. Correspondents include Hugh Grant Rowell, Lester Sleinkofer, Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Indian Rights Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oldest Indian welfare organization in United States. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $9,000, 1924. Controversy between several Indian welfare groups over religious liberty. Later requests declined. Correspondents include Arthur Woods, Kenneth Chorley.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Institute of International Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Student and professor exchange program, supported mainly by Carnegie and Ford grants. Family interest in Institute's activities; declinations of most invitations and appeals. Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial and Rockefeller Brothers Fund grants; occasional personal contributions. Correspondents include Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, Dr. Stephen Duggan, Laurance Duggan, Kenneth Holland, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

League gave Laurance S. Rockefeller information in connection with work of ORRRC. Correspondents include Kenneth Chorley, Dana S. Creel, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Carl O. Gustafson.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Japan Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. invited to membership, 1907; declined this and various other appeals and invitation. No material for 1923-1951. In 1951, John D. Rockefeller 3rd became interested in newly reviving Society. Early memos on what kind of program new Society should attempt: cultural exchange, a meeting place for those interested in Japan - catalyst-type activity. In 1952, John D. Rockefeller 3rd became president; John Foster Dulles, Chairman of Board till 1952. Early activities setting up program, membership, etc. Doug Overton became Executive Secretary. John D. Rockefeller 3rd 1953 article regarding Society. Overton memos on budget and activities; polls on American attitude toward Japan; miscellaneous correspondence; scholarships; membership lists. 1956 monograph on Japanese economy; 1957 Annual Report; 1961 Address by Douglas MacArthur, Jr.; 1961 Japan Societies Conference. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Don McLean, Jr., Douglas Overton, Raymond Kramer, Kenneth Holland, Edgar B. Young.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Municipal Art Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans for a music and art center in New York City. Mayor Fiorello La Guardia sparked plan; Nelson A. Rockefeller and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller involved in discussion since the Museum of Modern Art was to be included. Nelson A. Rockefeller's contribution to planning of proposed center and financial contributions to cost of studies. Robert Moses put in charge of plans, 1938; 1938 study suggested plans for center be delayed. In 1940, idea dropped; Nelson A. Rockefeller expressed his belief that New York City would ultimately have such a center. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Fiorello La Guardia, Robert Moses.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - National Audubon Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1909, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller became members; in 1919, Life Members. 1922 conditional pledge, lapsed. 1928 pledge. Society projects, pamphlets on national parks, the threat to ducks, roseate spoonbills, etc.; formation of rebel Emergency Conservation Committee, power and policy struggle, sniping action through the years between Committee and Society; formation of International Committee for Bird Protection, 1930. Reports, financial statements. Correspondents include Gilbert Pearson, John Baker, Carl Buchheister, Dana S. Creel, Arthur W. Packard, Thomas B. Appeget, David Rockefeller.

Packard, Thomas B. Appeget, David Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - National Parks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s 1924 letter regarding Glacier Park, his interest in legislation to acquire private lands within parks. Kenneth Chorley's 1928 report on national park system. Ouachita controversy; proposed Williamsburg; Jamestown historical national park. Arthur W. Packard's 1930 criticisms of National Park Association. 1931 lists of family and foundation contributions to parks. Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes's 1933 speech regarding John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and national parks. Drury's 1947 remarks on system; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s 1954 correspondence with Eisenhower regarding parks' deterioration. Laurance S. Rockefeller interest in junior museums. Various project appeals by individuals and groups, usually declined. Correspondents include Arno Cammerer, Robert Yard, Horace Albright, Kenneth Chorley, Arthur W. Packard, Arthur Woods, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Rockefeller became member in 1955, but file deals more with Moses, who comes through very clearly for those interested, than with Laurance S. Rockefeller. Pamphlets on New York Park system; master plan for Niagara frontier parks and parkways; correspondence regarding parkway speed limits, etc. Correspondents include Robert Moses, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - South Calaveras Grove

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. asked to help save California tract of Redwoods and largest pines in the world; his reluctance after Jackson Hole experiences. Peace-making correspondence with Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interested, but declined 1947 appeals. In 1954, he gave $1,000,000 to help purchase land. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Willard Van Name, Horace Albright, Harold L. Ickes.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Linville Falls Project

scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $100,000 to National Park Service to purchase North Carolina area connected to Blue Ridge Parkway. Photos; letters of appreciation. Correspondents include Horace Albright, Conrad Wirth, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Long Island Park Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Dinosaur National Monument

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congressional battle over whether two dams should be constructed in Monument, thus flooding much of the area. Transcripts of public hearing; statements by Representative Hosmer; pamphlets. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. declined to enter the fray. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Save the Redwoods League

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $2,000,000 toward purchase of Redwood groves. Raymond B. Fosdick investigated area; Rockefeller family visited area. Requests for further aid declined. Jay Downer consulted on road building. 1953 Saturday Evening Post article on Redwoods and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contribution of $25,000 to help establish Madison Grant Forest and elk refuge. Erosion problem. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Jay Downer, DeForest Grant, Horace Albright.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Jackson Hole Property - JY Ranch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1931, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. brought ranch for family's personal use and for future transmittal to Teton Park. Appraisal, addition of adjacent lands. Visits of sons, family friends, noted personages, etc., to ranch; correspondence with Fabian, Chorley and Mathews regarding upkeep, projects, improvements on property. Various photographs, maps, and blueprints. Correspondents include Arthur Woods, Kenneth Chorley, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Harold Fabian, Red Mathews, Herbert Hoover, Harry Truman.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organization of Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. (JHPI) as successor to Snake River Land Company; to be a "charitable" organization to hold lands. Laurance S. Rockefeller President; plans for Preserve. Extension of idea to include Wild Game Preserve; operation of JY Ranch; purchases of privately owned land. JHPI owned Grand Teton Lodge and Transportation Company. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s plans for conservation gifts through JHPI; Virgin Island project beginnings. Changing program of JHPI. Correspondents include Kenneth Chorley, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Harold Fabian, Conrad Wirth.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. - John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Gifts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gifts to Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. (JHPI) for purchase of privately owned land in Grand Teton and other parks (South Calaveras Grove, Virgin Islands, Cypress Sanctuary), for construction of lodges, and for general conservation. Totaled approximately $21,000,000 from John D. Rockefeller, Jr., plus $725,000 toward new hospital in Jackson Hole. $4,000,000 from Laurance S. Rockefeller. $2,000,000 from Rockefeller Brothers Fund. 1957 list of family contributions. Correspondents include Phillip Keebler, Kenneth Chorley, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

Rockefeller, Jr., Harold Fabian, Janus Simon, Fairfield Osborn.

Rockefeller, Jr., Harold Fabian, Janus Simon, Fairfield Osborn.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Jackson Hole Property - Appraisal of Property - Statement
Organizations and Parks - Jackson Hole Property - 1943 Offer and Controversy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. asked Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes to get action regarding Jackson Hole; 1943. Franklin Delano Roosevelt declared area a national monument, thus setting off 7-year battle involving Wyoming pressure groups vs. conservationists, state agencies vs. federal agencies, Congress vs. the Executive branch, Republican Party vs. Democratic Party. Attacks on John D. Rockefeller, Jr.; his attitude; his advisors' attempts to overcome opposition. 1949-1950 settlement; land finally given to government, 1949. File contains a great deal of interesting and detailed material on the struggle. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Kenneth Chorley, Horace Albright, Fairfield Osborne, F. Drury, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior Julius Albert Krug, Thomas Dewey, Senator O'Mahoney, and a cast of thousands.

In 1953, Committee becomes incorporated. 1954, By-Laws. Little Laurance S. Rockefeller activity here. Correspondents include Childs Frick, Harold Coolidge, Jr., Laurance S. Rockefeller.

Ordway, Jr., Fairfield Osborn, A. W. Smith, Leonard Outhwaite.

Rockefeller 3rd declined invitations to become assembly officers.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Paine Mexican Art Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: To assist in collection, distribution of Mexican pottery and other art. Abby Aldrich Rockefeller interested; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $10,000, 1928-1931. Correspondents include F. F. Paine, Thomas B. Appleget, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Philharmonic Society of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller contributed about $40,000, 1903-1917. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller dues paying members. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. introduced Henry Cooper into orchestral society, made personal appeal for orchestra in 1917 which brought new life into society. Orchestra problems; annual reports; annual deficit problem. Revised by-laws. Controversy over Saving Carnegie Hall. John D. Rockefeller 3rd 1955 letter was a harbinger of Lincoln Center. Margaret (Peggy) McGrath Rockefeller on Board; her memo regarding capital needs. Declinations of miscellaneous appeals and invitations. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Henry E. Cooper, Dana S. Creel, Thomas B. Appleget, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, David Keiser, Floyd Blair, Norman Davis.

scopecontent.p: Corporation organized to take over Philipse Castle and Sunnyside from the Tarrytown Historical Society. Dr. Rowell's salary and resignation. Cater's five-year development program; discussion of board membership; discussion of policy by Dana S. Creel and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dana S. Creel, Hugh Grant Rowell, H. D. Cater.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Avenue of the Americas Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly 6th Avenue Association. Group seeking to get "el" razed and area regenerated. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. a guest of honor at dinner celebrating opening of subway. Renaming of 6th Avenue. Projects for the future. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $6,000 for various projects. Miscellaneous correpondence. Correspondents include Charles O. Heydt, Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Colonel Jenkins.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Sons of the Revolution and Sons of the American Revolution

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two separate but similar patriotic organizations frequently confused with each other. John D. Rockefeller became member of New York chapter of Sons of the American Revolution, after search for proof of the required revolutionary ancestor, 1896. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Nelson A. Rockefeller declined to join. In 1934, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. became member of Virginia Chapter of Sons of the Revolution and donated money for several revolutionary war flags. John D. Rockefeller 3rd and David Rockefeller declined to join Sons of the Revolution. Declinations of appeals; right-wing literature from Major Hagood. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, Willard S. Richardson, Dana S. Creel, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., George Rogers, Major Hagood.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Sportsmanship Brotherhood

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Worked with high school boys through local group; stressed fair play. Nominal John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interest. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Mathew Woll, Arthur W. Packard, Daniel Chase.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Society of the Cincinnati

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Patriotic society founded in 1783, with George Washington as first president. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. an honorary member, 1929; in 1941, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $500; in 1948, he gave $500. In 1959, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. inherited $2.05 from Society member, declined it. All invitations and most appeals declined. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel.

scopecontent.p: An organization with funds looking for a program; awarded medals, aided starving artists, proposed International House project, which was dropped. No Rockefeller involvement. Correspondents include Carl Byoir, John D. Rockefeller 3rd.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Sloan Foundation - Laurance S. Rockefeller

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In 1950, Laurance S. Rockefeller joined Board of Trustees. Major objectives of Foundation; policy questions. Reports, projects, grants, additions to Board. Copies of several articles on the Foundation; report on Foundation investments. 1952 testimony for Cox investigation. Laurance S. Rockefeller dinner and speech on RBI, 1954. Amended agreement between Memorial Center and Foundation, 1958. Correspondents include Arnold Zurcher, Alfred Sloan, Jr., Karl Compton, Laurance S. Rockefeller.

Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller to be given to Society; John D. Rockefeller desk, pictures, chairs, books. Consideration of the Museum of the City of New York as alternate depository. Decision to discontinue Memorial Room; distribution of items to John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s children proposed. Correspondents John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dana S. Creel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Rowell's apprehensions regarding any future attempt to gain control of Philipse Castle as a source of personal profit; his desire for self-perpetuating Board. Proposed reorganization; the Todd Bill; changing of name to Historical Society of the Tarrytowns. New By-Laws. Correspondents include Thomas M. Debevoise, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., C. Belknap, Dr. Hugh Grant Rowell.

did.unittitle: Organizations and Parks - Elsie Janis Property - Philipse Manor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Manor first offered to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for apartment house development; Civic League obtained Abby Aldrich Rockefeller pledge toward purchase of house, 1931. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interested, but unwilling to help purchase it. Bank took over property through foreclosure, and Tarrytown Historical Society became actively interested. Up till 1939, no acceptable price was agreed upon between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and bank. Correspondents include Elsie Janis, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Hugh Grant Rowell.

did.unittitle: Palisades Interstate Park
Palisades Interstate Park - Palisades Park Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in 1902 urged passage of bill to extend power of Commission to protect Hudson banks; bill vetoed. From 1909-1910, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. helped raise funds for state park; John D. Rockefeller gave $500,000. In 1916, Foundation gave $1,000,000 toward park. Rockefeller gifts totaled $2,577,000 by 1938. By 1954, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s gifts alone exceeded $10,000,000. Property purchasing program; tributes to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for contributions. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Charles O. Heydt, Laurance S. Rockefeller, George Perkins.

did.unittitle: Radio - Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdicks Radio Services (National Vespers)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $500 to explore broadening of Fosdick's radio audiences, 1927. Also contributed heavily to expenses of weekly program. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and J. C. Colgate annually underwrote expenses; their contributions were cut as other contributions rose. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s share ranged from $2,000 to $4,000 until 1940s, when free will contributions from listeners covered all expenses. Program discontinued in 1945. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Harry Emerson Fosdick.

did.unittitle: Radio - World Wide Broadcasting Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Non-profit organization developing and broadcasting educational and peace-promoting programs over shortwave radio. Rockefeller Foundation was its main source of support in early years. Fund-raising report, 1940. FCC report on Foundation's stations, 1942. Some John D. Rockefeller 3rd involvement before World War II. Contributions by Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. Correspondents include Walter Leonard, Arthur W. Packard, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: French Restorations
French Restorations - Restorations in France

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. interest in Rheims, Versailles and Fontainebleau awakened while on trip through France in 1923. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. initiated action which led to gifts. Arthur Woods, Welles Bosworth, and George E. Vincent handled details in France. Letters of appreciation. Descriptions of re-opening ceremonies at Rheims. Contributions toward further restorations by Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Arthur Woods, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Welles Bosworth, George E. Vincent.

did.unittitle: French Restorations - Restorations in France - Versailles Ball
French Restorations - Restorations in France - Welles Bosworth Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. asks Bosworth to find out restoration requirements for Versailles, Rheims Cathedral, and Fontainebleau. Formation of Committee, with Bosworth a member as John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s representative. Bosworth's reports on meeting, progress of the work, problems of fluctuating francs and workmen; Bosworth's trip to Egypt to help Dr. James Breasted; his 1925 article on restorations. Work at Cite Universitaire. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s interest in government effort to purchase Hotel des Reservoirs; his desire to terminate his obligations by January 1, 1936. Steps taken to induce French to continue the work; decisions regarding allocation of surplus funds. Various honors for John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Disbanding of Committee. Bosworth paid $100,000, 1924-1936. Some later correspondence. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Welles Bosworth.

Colonial Williamsburg
Colonial Williamsburg - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Planning, mapping, assembling historical data, property purchases, dealings with townspeople. Historical manuscripts, photos, printed items regarding Virginia colonial history and early Williamsburg. Acquisition of mace for House of Burgesses. National Park Service; radio broadcasts; Williamsburg contributions to other organizations. Junior Chamber of Commerce report on city problems; anti-semitism and anti-negro sentiment. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Charles O. Heydt, Arthur Woods, Vernon Geddy, Thomas M. Deveboise, Kenneth Chorley, Robert Lecky, William A. R. Goodwin, W. Perry, Phillip Keebler, Robert W. Gumbel.

No close cooperation between groups, however. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Edwin R. Embree.

did.unittitle: Rosenbach Collection - Historic Documents

scopecontent.p: Purchase, repair and retention of documents in New York; "Carleton Papers" then transferred to Colonial Williamsburg after John D. Rockefeller, Jr. bought them from Rosenbach. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Kenneth Chorley, Arthur Woods, P. Rosenbach.

did.unittitle: Burgesses Corps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Armory Burgesses Corps of Albany, included many influential life honorary members. John D. Rockefeller declined membership in 1905, 1919. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. accepted life membership, 1914 and contributed $250. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. resigned in 1917. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.
